title: Armlet

  shape: irregular

  materials_name: gold (metal) metal

  techniques_name: repoussé jewellery making metalworking

  object_colour: gold (colour)

  physical_appearance: The image shows an armlet. It is gold in colour. Its shape is symmetrical. At its vertical line of symmetry
 three jewels can be discerned. The one at the top and the one hanging from a ring near the bottom are both grey in colour. In between these two grey jewels
 a purple one is situated just below the mouth of the k?rttimukha. There are motifs of birds as well as animal art such as lions and horses all over the armlet.

  subject_terms_1: jewellery ritual objects ornaments (object genre) Hinduism iconography birds (motif) goldwork (visual works) animal art k?rttimukhas decorative art (art genre) allover patterns

  subject_terms_2: Motifs Goldwork Gold jewellery Hinduism Ethnic jewellery Idols and images

  subject_terms_3: Jewellery Hinduism

  sgcool_label_text: In the southern Indian region
 jewellery is created keeping in mind several ritualistic needs of the various communities. The size and design of the ornament denoted the social background of the owner; some jewellery like the thali also declared the marital status of the wearer. This vanki or armlet is an elaborate example of repousse craftsmanship from Tamil Nadu. Stacked animal and bird motifs culminate in a central kirtimukha or face of glory. The kirtimukha is also placed centrally in the detail on the back.

metadata.physical_appearance: The image shows an armlet. It is gold in colour. Its shape is symmetrical. At its vertical line of symmetry, three jewels can be discerned. The one at the top and the one hanging from a ring near the bottom are both grey in colour. In between these two grey jewels, a purple one is situated just below the mouth of the k?rttimukha. There are motifs of birds as well as animal art such as lions and horses all over the armlet.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: In the southern Indian region, jewellery is created keeping in mind several ritualistic needs of the various communities. The size and design of the ornament denoted the social background of the owner; some jewellery like the thali also declared the marital status of the wearer. This vanki or armlet is an elaborate example of repousse craftsmanship from Tamil Nadu. Stacked animal and bird motifs culminate in a central kirtimukha or face of glory. The kirtimukha is also placed centrally in the detail on the back.
